sentences.sentence: Byron HollandJust when you thought 2020 had run out of surprises, Facebook pulled off the impossible.

Civil liberties groups, grassroots activists, multinational corporations and network operators like my group, the Canadian Internet Regulatory Authority (CIRA), have banded together to boycott the social media giant for its failure to curb the spread of fake news, misinformation and hate speech on its platform.Born during a global movement focused on racist police violence, the #StopHateForProfit campaign began in mid-June to curb the amplification of hate online.
Since then, household-name companies including Coca-Cola and Starbucks joined.

Even Canada's five largest banks have taken a stand.For our part, we have chosen to cease advertising on any Facebook platform and will reassess our position at the end of July based on the choices Facebook makes in the coming weeks.From our perspective as the technical operator of mission-critical internet infrastructure, widespread, ubiquitous amplification of hate speech, fake news and misinformation undermines trust online, which in turn hurts the safe, stable and secure functioning of the open internet.Google and Facebook should compensate news outlets.

The devil is in the details as to how(https://nationalpost.com/opinion/google-and-facebook-should-compensate-news-outlets-the-devil-is-in-the-details-as-to-how)Facebook staffers walk out in rare protest against Mark Zuckerberg's policies(https://nationalpost.com/news/world/facebook-staffers-walk-out-in-rare-protest-against-mark-zuckerbergs-policies)Unfortunately, Facebook has created an information system that champions sensationalism - not quality - above all else.
In the so-called "attention economy," information's importance, relevance or substance is not necessarily what matters.

What matters is how many likes, comments and shares digital content gets.To justify the harms brought by this approach, Facebook's apologists will say this is an acceptable tradeoff to protect free speech, but as we all know, free speech has reasonable limits.

Every society has set limits on the speech it thinks is appropriate to keep its people, economy and democracy safe.From our perspective, Facebook has failed to place reasonable limits on how dangerous speech is amplified.
The unchecked promotion of hate speech, fake news and misinformation on Facebook's platform is a problem that must be urgently addressed.The decision to pull our advertising was not easy.

It's no secret that Facebook holds significant power in the world of online advertising, which is essentially a duopoly.Countless small businesses are in a difficult spot with no good alternatives to Facebook to promote their business.

And, of course, many of these businesses are still gasping for air in the midst of the COVID-19 pandemic.Facebook Chairman and CEO Mark Zuckerberg testifies at a House Financial Services Committee hearing in Washington, U.S., October 23, 2019.Nothing about corporate self-interest and responsibility to shareholders would suggest that this should be happening right now.

And yet, Facebook's track record has suddenly made the once-impossible feel urgent and unavoidable.With the largest players in the business community united behind their displeasure with one of the world's largest advertising giants, governments should see this as a wake-up call.To date, the Cambridge Analytica scandal, massive data breaches, abuse of user data, poor security practices, psychological experiments, record-setting fines and countless other controversies have not been enough to meaningfully reform the social media giant.Facebook's power rivals anything we have witnessed in corporate history, from railroads to banks to oil to telecom.

While Facebook's product is one of the 21st century, its corporate culture shares much in common with the oligopolies and monopolies of the past - namely, its capacity to harm its customers and competitors with little to no consequence.It's been clear for some time that Facebook believes it knows best, even if that means ignoring the complaints and requests of its over two billion users - but this arrogance can be deadly for companies.A pedestrian wearing a mask walks along Dundas Street West in Toronto past a poster stating "Wanted Theft Of News Content" refering to Facebook founder and owner Mark Zuckerberg and his company's media usage practises, June 3, 2020.That a movement of multinational corporations, civil liberties groups and grassroots activists can come together during a global pandemic should serve as a wake-up call for Facebook and lawmakers around the world.As protesters around the world rally against abusive, unaccountable, concentrated power in the hands of law enforcement, it is perhaps unsurprising that a parallel movement should emerge to fight the concentrated power of a company that controls so much of the circulation of our culture, our politics and our economy.For now, we are optimistic that the advertiser boycott can help signal to Facebook that it is time for change.

But we recognize that until we create more competition in the online marketing sector, there will be limits to how effectively Facebook can be reined in.The only question that remains is how lawmakers and Facebook management choose to act over the coming days, week, and months of the boycott.National PostByron Holland is president and CEO of the Canadian Internet Registration Authority, which manages the.CA domain on behalf of Canadians.
